DIV1.P: As it hath beene often Acted with good Applause, at the Globe, and Black-Fryers. By his Maiesties Servants.
DIV1.Q: Hic totus volo rideat Libellus. Mart.
DIV1.P: LONDON: Printed by AVG. MATHEVVES, and are to be sold by NICHOLAS VAVASOVR, dwelling at the little South dore of St. Pauls Church. 1632.

LIST.HEAD: The Persons in the Comedie.
LIST.ITEM: Sir Phillip Lucklesse, Contracted to Mistresse Fitchow the Citie Widdow.
Master Tridewell, Kinsman to Sir Phillip.

Iustices; Mistresse Fitchows friends.
Sir Paul Squelch
Master Bulsinch
Master Widgine a Cockney-Gentleman, Brother to Mi∣stresse Fitchow.
Anuile, a Braggart, Governour to Widgine.
Master Non-sence a Cornish Gentleman, Suiter to Con∣stance.
Pate, a witty Seruingman to Sir Phillip.
Beauis, a blunt Seruingman to Mistresse Traynwell.
Howdye, Mistresse Fitchows man and Gentleman Vsher.
Con. Hold up, a cunning Whore.

DIV1.HEAD: TO THE RIGHT WOR∣THY AND NO LESSE IVDI∣cious then ingenious Gentleman RICHARD HOLFORD Esquire.
DIV1.P:
RIch Friends may send you rich Pre∣sents, while poore ones haue no∣thing but good wishes to present you. Though I bee one of the last ranke, and therefore cannot doe like the first, yet it is my ambition to bring more then bare wishes with me, to one of whom I haue recei∣ued reall favours A Countrey Lasse I present you, that Minerua-like was a brayn-borne child; and Iouially begot, though now shee seekes her fortune▪ Shee came out of the cold North, thin∣ly clad: But Wit had pitty on her; Action ap∣parrell'd her, and Plaudits clap'd her cheekes warme. Shee is honest, and modest, though she speake broad: And though Art neuer strung her tongue; yet once it yeelded a delightfull
sound: which gain'd her many Lovers and Friends, by whose good liking she prosperously liued, vntill her late long Silence, and Disconti∣nuance (to which shee was compell'd) gaue her iustly to feare their losse, and her owne de∣cay. Wherefore shee, now, destrous to settle her selfe in some worthy seruice; And no way wil∣ling (like some of further breed) to returne from this Southern sunshine, back to her natiue Ayre; I thought it might become my care (having first brought and estrang'd her from her Countrey) to sue, with her, for Your noble Patronage; of Whom, shee heares, (if Flattery abuse her not) shee hath, heretofore, gotten some good opini∣on. Your loue to witty, and pleasant Recreati∣ons of this nature hath brought her on: And Northern Spirits will soone wex bold. If you be pleased to accept of her, shee will travaile no further; but, together with my selfe, remaine

CLOSER.SIGNED: Euer at your seruice, RIC. BROME.

DIV1.HEAD: To my old Faithfull Seruant: and (by his continu'd Vertue) my louing Friend: the Author of this Work, M. RICH. BROM.
DIV1.L: I Had you for a Seruant, once, Dick Brome;
And you perform'd a Seruants faithfull parts:
Now, you are got into a nearer roome,
Of Fellowship, professing my old Arts.
And you doe doe them well, with good applause,
Which you haue iustly gained from the Stage,
By obseruation of those Comick Lawes
Which I, your Master, first did teach the Age.
You learn'd it well; and for it, seru'd your time
A Prentise-ship: which few doe now a dayes.
Now each Court-Hobby-horse will wince in rime;
Both learned, and vnlearned, all write Playes.
It was not so of old▪ Men tooke vp trades
That knew the Crafts they had bin bred in, right:
An honest Bilbo-Smith Would make good blades,
And the Physician teach men spue, or shite;
The Cobler kept him to his nall; but, now
Hee'll be a Pilot, scarce can guide a Plough.

DIV1.HEAD: To his approued Friend M. RICHARD BROME on his Northern Lasse.
DIV1.L: VVHat! wilt thou prostitute thy Mistresse, (Friend)
And make so rich a Beauty common! What end
Do'st thou propose▪ Shee was thine owne, but now
All will enioy her free: 'tis strange that thou
Canst brooke so many Rialls in thy Lasse,
Whose Wit and Beauty does her Sex surpasse.
I'ue learnt it; Thou hast tri'd her, found her chast,
And fear'st not that Shee'll lewdly be embrac't:
And now thou sendst her to be seen, and see
If any be like faire, like good as Shee.

DIV1.HEAD: To his ingenious Brother M RICH. BROME, vpon this witty issue of his Brayne, the Northern Lasse.
DIV1.L: ALthough I call you by a Brothers name,
I must confesse (nor doe I feare the shame)
I am in loue with your faire Daughter, this,
As faire condition'd as her Father is.
Well met abroud, blithe, bonny, Northern Lasse:
Thy naturall Beauties, others farre surpasse
That are enrich'd with Fucusses of Art,
Thy witty sweetnesse beares so faire a part.
Not a Good woman, nor a Girle worth Gold,
Nor twenty such (whose gaudy shewes take hold
Of gazing eyes) shall in acceptance thriue
With thee, whose quaintnesse is superlatiue.
Dick may be proud shee's Daughter to no other;
As I am proud that I haue such a Brother.

DIV1.HEAD: Of Mr. RICHARD BROME his ingenious Comedy, the Northern Lasse, To the Reader.
DIV1.L: POets and Paynters curiously compar'd
Giue life to Fancie; and atchieue Reward
By Immortality of Name: So thriues
Art's Glory, that All, what it breahes on, liues.
Winesse this Northern Piece. The Court affords
No newer fashion, or for Wit, or Words.
The Body of the Plot is drawne so faire,
That the Soules language quickens, with fresh ayre,
This well limb'd Poëm, by no Rate, or Thought
Too dearely priz'd, being or sold, or bought.

CLOSER.SIGNED: IOHN FORD The Authors very Friend.

DIV1.HEAD: To my Sonne BROME and his. Lasse.
DIV1.L: VVHich, then of Both shall I commend?
Or Thee (that art my Sonne and Friend)
Or Her, by Thee begot▪ A Girle
Twice worth the Cleopatrian Pearle.
No: 'tis not fit for Me to Grace
Thee, who art Mine; and to thy Face.
Yet I could say, the merries Mayd
Among the Nine, for Thee has luyd
A Ghyrlond by; and Iieres to see
Pied Ideots teare the Daphnean Tree;
Putting their Eyes out with those Boughes
With which Shee bids me deck thy Browes.
But what I bring shall crowne thy Daughter
(My Grand child) who (though full of laughter)
I Chast and Witty to the Time;
Not Lumpish-Cold, as is her Clime
By Phoebus Lyre, Thy Northern Lasse
Our Southern proudest Beauties passe:
Be Iouiall with thy Braynes (her Mother)
And helpe her (Dick) to such Another.

DIV1.HEAD: To his knowne Friend Mr. R BROME on his Northern Lasse.
DIV1.L: MY Loue may wrong the, Friend; and, should I praise
Thy Booke, I 'twould stayne the wreathing Bayes
That crownes thy Head: No, they that know, can tell
This Piece craues not a bribing Prayer to sell.
Here's Beauty, Wit, and Language in a Glasse.
Who would not haue a Copy of this Lasse?

DIV1.HEAD: Prologue.
DIV1.L: GAllants, and Friends-spectators, will yee see
A strayne of Wit that is not Poetrie?
I haue Authority for what I say:
For He himselfe sayes so, that Writ the Play,
Though, in the Muses Garden he can walke;
And choycest Flowers pluck from euery stalke
To deck the Stage; and purposeth, hereafter,
To take your Iudgements: now He implores your laughter;
Sayes He would see you merry; thinks it long
Since you were last delighted with a Song.
Your Bookes, he sayes, can shew you History;
And serious Passages better then Hee;
And that He should take paines in Act to show
What you already by your Studies know
Were a presumption. Tis a Modestie
Vn-vs'd 'mongst Poets. This being onely Hee
That boasteth not his worth; and doth subscrib
Himselfe an vnder-seruant in their Tribe.
Yet though he slight himselfe, We not despaire,
By him, to shew you what is Good and Rare.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: BVt I beseech you sir, Take me somewhat nearer your Councell. May I assure my selfe, that this report goes true; that you are on this treaty of Marriage with that Widow?

SP.SPEAKER: Luc
SP.P: Faith cosen, I take it as my fortune; and m fully bent on the aduenture.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Troth in my mind, you were better venture your selfe, and fortune to the Bermudas. Tis true, shee has a good estate: some nine thousand, I thinke: and were an apt match for one that knew how to governe it, and her; some hard bred Cittizen, crafty Lawyer, or countrey Iustice. But you, a tender Nureling of the Court, altogether vnmixt with such nature or education, to cast your selfe vpon her, who for her yeares might be your Mother (they say: I ne∣ver saw her) and has beene the Towne widow these three yeares, still conversant with Doctors, and Proctors of the civill Law; of which Tribe her husband was too. Never looke to bee the better for her Riches: Shee'll consume yours and you too▪ though your backe were Herculean; and lay you in your graue, or in Bedlem (my life on't) before she dreame o' dying, though it be all that you can hope, or pray for, after Mariage.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: You speake sir out of some vnfortunate examples, and your extraordinary care of me. But truth is, all deswa∣sion comes too late; and all vrgings against it are now vn∣charitable: For wee are already Man and Wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: What married!

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Lustily promis'd sir. Absolutely contracted.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Send you ioy. Ile out of Towne.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: I hope you'll see our Mariage. I sent indeed to bid you.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: No, good sir Phillip, rather then I would be in sound of a Bell that should ring at it, I would haue my braines fil∣lipt out with the Clapper.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Nay good cosen: I intended you my principall Guest. Wee'll haue all very priuate: not aboue foure or fiue friends more.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Sir, I intend to bee none of your Mourners, which indeed my presence there would mke mee; and so, perhaps, infect the rest. I leaue my best wishes to you, and will in∣deauour to pray for you. Indeed I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Indeed this is very abrupt.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: Mr. Tridewall! well met. Why so fast sir, I tooke you for a Foot-post.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: A Foot-post! Indeed your fine wit will post you into another world one of these dayes, if it take not the whip∣ping post i' the way. And why Foot-post, in your little wit∣ty apprehension?

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: Because you went so fast. Bt since you are angry, I would you were going twise as last. If I interrupt you, hang me. Dee heare?

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Nay I know you are apt to decline any mans anger, good Captaine Anvile: you haue beene beaten to't.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Why, if he haue, hee may thanke such as you are, that can endure no iest.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: What are you there too? Mr. Widgine, I take it?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: My name is Walter Widgine sir, not to be denyed▪ the only brother here of sir Phillip Lucklesse his betroch'd. She is a Widgine borne sir, and of the best family: Our Ancestors flew out of Holland in Lincolnshire to preuent perication.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: From Crowland, I warrant you, a little before a Moulting time.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Like enough sir. My sister can tell you. Since, by mar∣riage, shee was made a Fitchow: Her husband was Fitchow the civill Lawyer; Hee was call'd the great Cannor of the civill Law: because he could dischardge or make report of euery Canon therein; Canon after Canon, or Canon vp∣on Canon at his fingers ends, as readily as I can tell these peeces.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: A faire Demonstration!

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: He had many rare parts in him, besides sir, as my sister can tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: This fellow cannot chuse but haue a rare sister: Hee quotes her so!

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: But all the good I can speake of him is, that he left my sister rich; or at least a reasonable estate, halfe a score thousand pounds or so: which shee, with her selfe, bestowes vpon this honourable knight sir Phillip Luckles, to bee a La∣dy▪ of that name, and God gi' him ioy. And for you: being his kinsman, I shall desire your neerer acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: In good time sir.

SP.SPEAKER: VVid.
SP.P: The match was not altogether her owne seeking sir, though she refus'd two Aldermen for him, on my owne knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Might shee haue had'hem both sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: I and halfe a score Aldermens fellowes to boote: yet refus'd all for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: In deed sixe yoake of such cattell would plow vp all his acres in a forenoone.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: My sister can tell you more sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Still shee is his Authority. I will see this woman. Sir Phillip, here are Guests will applaud your match. Bid'hem welcome▪ God buy.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid▪
SP.P:
For my part I honour any Man, that marries my
sister. Sir Phillip, and my noble brother in expectation, I pray embrace my Governour, Captaine Anvile, here; and giue him and me our gloues: you shall find him worthy your acquaintance. Hee has wit, I can tell you; and breakes as many good iests as all the VVits, Fits, and Fancies about the Towne, and has traind vp many young gentlemen, both here, and in diuers parts beyond the Seas. Hee was dry nurse (thats one of his owne iests vpon himselfe) to the English youth, a dozen yeares together beyond Sea: And now he is my Governour, and I find profit in it: you cannot thinke what an asse I was before I met with him: And I meane to trauell with him, two or three yeares hence, my selfe. In the meane time, he shall spend a hundred a yeare out of Wat Widgines purse. Sha't faith Governour, what aylest thou? art thou not right?

SP.SPEAKER: Anv.
SP.P: I shall find a time to right my selfe, I doubt not.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: But will you trauell at these yeares Mr Widgine?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Will you not call me brother? Two dayes hence when you haue married my sister, you must. Must hee not, Governour?

SP.SPEAKER: Anv.
SP.P: Yes an't please him.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Hee ayles something.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: VVell then, Brother two dayes hence, will you trauell?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: I some two yeares hence, mistake me not. I know I am but young yet: besides I meane to marry first as other young heires doe. And then towry lowry, faith, my noble Governour, and I! Twill be braue going into France then: I may learne halfe their fashions before I goe, and bate so much, being taught at when I come there. VVhats the mat∣ter Governour? thou wert not wont to bee thus. Is thy money all gone? Heres fiue peeces to buy pomps against my sisters wedding.

SP.SPEAKER: Anv.
SP.P: Haue I eyes and eares, and can thinke of trifling Money matters?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P:
Pox on't I had forgot. That sciruy surly gentleman angerd him ere while, and put him out of patience. How the hot ome of his rage boyles out at his Mouth▪ If I durst
goe so neere the heate of him I would skim the pot.

SP.SPEAKER: Anv.
SP.P: If I try not this Tridewell; put him to the dearest tryall of his life.—

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: I there tis, he will never come to himselfe till he beat, or bee beaten.

SP.SPEAKER: Anv.
SP.P: Let me haue these knockd out; these puld off; these pluckd out, and these sawd off.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: I must venter on him. Nay Governour: pray thee consider.—

SP.SPEAKER: Anv.
SP.P: The time and place you meane. Thinke you hee durst haue done it, but in his kinsmans house; hee and the multitude of his seruants present.

SP.SPEAKER: VVid.
SP.P: I, and wee know not how many arm'd men in the next roome. Hearke Governour.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: What things are these! I shall marry into a fine stocke! How vntimely some considerations fall into my mind▪ My Cosens councell, which hath ever beene oracu∣lously good; against which I violently beare my selfe, to mixe my blood amongst a race of fooles. Had but these thoughts beene mine but one day past, they had preuented all that may proue dangerous in this, so great and doubtfull vndertaking.

DIV3.HEAD: Act. I. Sce. III.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Pate, to Luckles, VVidgine, Anvile.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: Sir, there's a gentlewoman would speake with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Who is it? Doe you not know her?

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: I never saw her before sir. I askt her name. But I per∣ceiu'd some displeasure in her looke (whether it were shame, griee, or anger I know not) that made her conceale it: On∣ly telling me shee was a woman very hurtlesse, and warran∣table against your feare.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P:
I warrant tis my sister. Shee frownd, did shee not, and look'd fightingly? If shee did, 'tis my sister, your wife that shall be. Shee will looke so at you, I can tell you, or me, or my Governour, for all he is a Captaine. Shee feares no colours I faith, to tell you true, shee beate him once for a
iest he broke vpon her Monkey. Is it not shee, thinkst thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: No sir it is not shee. I know my Lady that shall be.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: My Lady that shall bee! how sweetly it chimes. Heres something for that word.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Goe bring her vp. Good brother VVidgine, fly in∣to the next roome, with your Governour. Ile waite on you presently.

SP.SPEAKER: VVid.
SP.P: My Lady! And brother VVidgine! I must admire. Our house is rays'd by this two stories higher.—

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: There's no recalling time; and vowes of this high nature are no trifles.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: Sir I suppose you are sir Phillip Luckles.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: I am the man Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: And you are shortly to marry a Citty Widdow, one Mistresse Fitchow?

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Most true.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: For whose deare sake you purchas'd a foure hun∣dred pounds knighthood, to goe a woing in: out of which shee is to giue nine thousand pounds for a Ladiship for terme of life.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: What meane you Gentlewoman?

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: Sir not to scold, or brawle, (a vice to frequent in our Sexe.) But, in few words (and ciuill ones) to make you sen∣sible of a little of that infinite iniury, you haue done to one, whose vnvaluable portion of vertue makes her fit, (besides the right shee has already in you) to take a brides place, be∣fore your later choy, or any shee, whose wealth might weigh downe hers. You stand as if you knew not who I meane.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Nor what neither. Sure my name's abus'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: Pray sir bethinke your selfe. Has there not beene a former contract made betwixt you and some other.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: No. Nor any faithfull promise neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: That I may well beleeue, when you forget it.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: I pray speake nearer to my vnderstanding: whom may you suggest to be the woman o much forgotten?

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: If you haue soule, or sense, you must remember her: No? Read then her name subscrib'd to that.
SP.L: If pitty, loue, or thought of me,
Liue in your breast I need not die.
But if all these from thence be fled;
Liue you to know, that I am dead.
SP.P: Farewell good Constance. I am sorry I haue no further for thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: Doe you know that name sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Yes Lady so well, that I am sorry, that a gentlewo∣man of your good seeming should haue to doe for so light a peece of vanity. Leaue going o'the devills Errants: His kingdomes large enough, and too much peopled already.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Pray sir, are you in sober earnest?

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: I good faith am I.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: You are vnhappy then. For you shall loose, in this disdaine of yours, more honour then your life time in repen∣tance can recover. So fare you well sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Farewell old Whiskin. Slid Ile marry out o' the way; tis time I thinke: I shall bee tane vp for whores meat else. Constance! shee had a Bastard tother day too. What a mischeiuous Maw has this shee Caniball that gapes for mee! Slight a common Trader, with I know not how many! I maruell shee was left out of Cupids Muster. Sure shee bribd the Ballat-maker: One that I haue paid at all times too; heres one, there's tother▪ And now shee heares I am to∣wards mariage pretends a claime to mee. And what a Mi∣nister shee had procur'd! A Divell in a most gentlewoman∣like apparition. It had beene well to haue pumpd her. Is shee gone?

SP.SPEAKER: Pate.
SP.P: Who sir, the Gentlewoman? I put her in her coach.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Her Coache! Coaches must needs bee common, when their cariages are so. By this light, Oliver, a Bawd; a very Bawd. Where's my brother Widgine, and his Gover∣nour, Anvile! They are wholsomer company o' the two, yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: A Bawd I Blesse my Masters wits. But the best is, if hee be mad, there's that at hand will tame him, or any man: A fine Cooler, call'd Mariage, to take his batchelors button a hle lower! Can it bee possible? Shee might ha' beene Mother o' the Maydes, as well, to my seeming; or a Matron, to haue traind vp the best Lady Daughters in the Countrie. Here comes her Man, againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.P: Is sir Phillip Lucklesse i' the house still sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: Are you the Cock-bawd to the hen was here, ere while sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.P: Are you mad, or are you drunke sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: Cme you to bargaine for a Punke sir? Faith where's the meeting? Wher's the Supper? at the Bridgefoot, or the Cat? or where is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.P: Nay then sir, though your Master be allowd to mea∣sure his manners, by his pleasure, here, on his owne yard, Ile bee bold to pull you out on't by the eares, and beat you into better fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: Hold, hold. Pray hold a little sir. I cry you mercy. I might bee mistaken. I see thou art a good fellow. I haue halfe a dozen for thee faith. S' foot what big words and ter∣rible action he has! Is this the Bawds language? Pray par∣don me sir: I haue beene overwatch'd of late, and knew nei∣ther place, person, not what I said at the instant.

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.P: Indeed?

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P:
I sir, tis an infirmity I am much troubled withall; a kind of a—betweene steepe and waking—I know not what to call it. I would giue tvventie nobles to bee cured on't. I pray take it not ill sir; I vse any man so, when the fits on
mee, till they throughly wake mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.P: What as I did now? by the eares? Are you come to your selfe enough yet? or shall I helpe you further sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: No, tis very well now I thanke you sir. Alas I put my Master to the paines, twise or thrise a weeke, I assure you, to my griefe.

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.P: A very strange disease! How might you get it?

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: Faith I fell into 't first, with a conceit I tooke for overbuying a bargaine of Drinke. Your businesse with my Master sir? I pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.P: Onely to speake with him from the Gentlewoman was here eene now.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: I shall acquaint him with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.P: I shall be your seruant.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: I pray pardon my error.

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.P: And you my boldnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: O not so sir. Well master Pimp I haue a plot vpon your imployment, as brauely as you carry it. I know he is a Bawd by his out-facing. And I doe humble and disguise my Manhood to worke on him by policy: And if I put not a fine slurre vpon him for all his braue brauados, then Oliver Pate has no braines; nor is there any difference betwixt a Seruing-man and a Pandar.—

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.P: What a Trim-tram trick is this? the Master and the Man both brain-cras'd; as the one vsed me, so did the other my Mistris. But I haue brought this into a kind of civill sense againe. Doe wee looke like Bawds? There is some strange ground for this mistaking. I am sure shee has ever beene reputed a vertuous Gentlewoman; and has now the governement, and bringing vp of a Virgin, of a most hope∣full goodnesse. And I thinke, I know my selfe; and dare beat any Man into a better construction of my quality.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P:
Now wit, and bee thy will! Sir, my Master desires to bee excused: for he is with some friends, on priuate bu∣sines, concerning his Mariage; which is to be to morrow. But sayes, if it please you to meet him in the Euening, be∣tweene foure, and fiue, in the great Pallace; and condnuct
him to the Gentlewoman, hee will attend her with his best seruice.

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.P: Betweene foure, and fiue in the Pallace: but how shall I know him? I neuer saw him.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: As I wish'd: But you may easily. Hee is of a come∣ly stature; and will be in a red cloae and a white Feather, Besides Ile waite on him.

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.P: I thanke you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: Fare you well sir. Good Foist, I shall make a Whiskin of you now, and for nothing too. I haue beene a little bold with my Masters name in this answere; the know∣ledge of which he is vnguilty of. I saw how he shifted her off: Therefore I will further bee bold both with his name and person, which I will put vpon a friend in store. My spe∣ciall friend, Captaine Anvile, a notable lecherous Tuppe: He has beene at me for a bit out of my Masters flocke any time these three weekes. Ile pleasure him with her for rea∣dy money. I know tis some cast stuffe, that my Master has done withall. And let him take what followes.

DIV3.HEAD: Act. I. Sce. VI.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Fitchow, Howdee, with Inke and Paper.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Well sir. And what said Master Lucklesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.P: Sir Phillip you meane forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: The very same sir. But I beginne to call him now, as I must call him hereafter. Ladies doe not call their hus∣bands, as they are Knights: as sir Phillip, sir Timothy, or sir Gregory. Did you ever heare my Lady Squelch call her hus∣band sir Paul? No. But master Squelch. Indeed all others must sir them by their Christen names; because they are Knights, and to bee knowne from other men: onely their owne wiues must master them, by their Sirnames; because they are Ladies, and will not know them from other men. But to our busines. What said he to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.P: His worship said forsooth—

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Nay, What said you to him first? I loue to heare things in order.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.P: I said that as you bad me forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: As I bad you, Clotpoll? what was that? Shall I ever mould thee into a Gentleman Vsher thinkst thou, that stand'st so? Come forwards sir, and repeat.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.P: My Mistris commends her best loue vnto your Wor∣ship; and desires to know how your Worship came home last night; and how your Worship haue rested; and how your Worship dos this morning? Shee hopes the best of your Worships health; and would be glad to see your Wor∣ship at your Worships best leasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: This was very well: word for word as I instructed. But did you worship him so much?

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.P: Yes truly, and hee commended mee for it; and said I shew'd my breeding.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Now sir. His answere? in his owne words.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.P: Quoth hee. I thanke thy Mistris, and I thanke thee. Prithee commend my seruice to her, and tell her, my wor∣ship came home vpon my worships Foot-cloath; my wor∣ship tooke very good rest, in my worships bed: My wor∣ship has very little to doe this Morning, and will see her at my worships leasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Did hee say so?

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.P: Twas either so, or so much I am sure. But he did not make me repeat, as you did, till I had cond it by heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Well Howdie get you downe. And oe you heare Howdee? If sir Paul Squelch come, bring him vp.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.P: I will forsooth Mistris.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: I bad you learne to call me Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.P: I shall forsooth Ma-dame.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: You shall forsooth Madame. Tis but a day to't; and I hope one may be a Lady one day before her time.

SP.SPEAKER: How.
SP.P: A day too soone doubt in this forward age.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: In the meane time, let me study my remembrances for after mariage.

Imprimis, To haue the whole sway of the house; and all domesticall affaires; as of accounts of houshold chardges, placing and displacing of all seruant in generall; To haue free liberty, to goe on all my visits; and though my knights occasions bee never so vrgent, and mine of no moment, yet
to take from him the command of his Coach; To be in spe∣ciall fee with his best trusted seruant; nor to let one liue with him, that will not bewray all his counsells to mee. To study and practise the Art of iealousie; To faine anger, me∣lancholly, or sicknsse, to the life. These are Arts that wo∣men must bee well practis'd in, ere they can attaine to wise∣dome, and ought to be the onely study of a widow, from the death of her first husband, to the second: From the second to the third, matters of deeper moment; From the third to the fourth deeper yet; And so proportionably to the sea∣uenth, if shee be so long blest with life: But of these I may finde time hereafter to consider in order as they fall. Besides, in all, to be singular in our will; to raigne, gouerne, ordaine lawes and breake 'hem, make quarrells and maintaine 'him; professe truthes, deuise falshoods; protest obedience, but study nothing more then to make our husbands so; Con∣trole, controuert, contradict, and be contrary to all confor∣mity: To which end wee must be sure to be arm'd alwayes with prick and praise of the deceased; and cary the Inuen∣tory of our goods, and the grosse summe of our Dowry per∣petually in our mouthes. Then dos a husband tickle the spleene of a woman, when shee can anger him to please him; chide him to kisse him; Mad him to humble him; make him stiffe necked to supple him; and hard-hearted to breake him; to st him vp, and take him downe, and vp againe, and downe againe, when, and as often as we list.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.P: Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: I marry, now thou say'st well.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.P: Andt please your Ladiship.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Well said againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.P: One M. Tridewell, Gentleman, desires to speak with your Ladiship, from Sir Phillip.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Tridewell! O it is Sir Phillips Kinsman. I haue heard him speake much good of him; and entreated mee to giue him good respect; which were enought to marre his enter∣tainment, had I not another purpose of mine owne, that may proue as ill. Bring him vp Howdee.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.P: I will Madame—

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: I that was very well. This Howde doe I meane with a cast Gowne to put in apparell, and make my Gentle∣man Vsher; Not onely for the aptnesse of his name, to goe on my visits; but for his proportionable talent of wit and manners.

DIV3.HEAD: Act. I. Sce. VII.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: If I can yet redeeme him, he is happy. By your leaue Lady: May my boldnesse proue pardonable?

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Sir the name of him, you come from, is warrant suf∣ficient to make your welcome here: All that is here be∣ing his.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Is this shee trow!

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: I vnderstand you come from Sir Phillip Luckles.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: 'Tis true, I brought his name thus farre to enter mee to your presence. But here I shake it off, as I would doe his remembrance: but that I know him too well.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Too well Sir? How meane you?

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Too well indeede Lady; but in the ill part. I know him to be no equall Match for you. Yet I heare you receiue him as a Suter.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Right Sir. and him onely.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: It is not gone so farre I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Beshrew mee but it is; and farther too Sir. Hee has all wooed and wonne me.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.L: Beshrew your fortune then. And if my counell;
The friendliest counsell e're you hearkned to,
Stop not your ventrous foote from one step further,
(For now you are vpon the brinke of danger)
You fall into a Sea of endlesse sorrowes.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.L: This is pretty!

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.L: Looke back into your selfe; read o're your Story,
Finde the content the quiet minde you liu'd in,
The wealth, the peace, the pleasure you enioy'd;
The free command of all you had beneath you,
And noe to be commanded by aboue you.
Now glaunce your eye on this side, on the yoake,
You bring your neck to, lden downe with cares,
Where you shall faintly draw a tedious life,
And euery step incounter with new strife.
Then, when you groane beneath your burdenous charge,
And wearily chance to reuert a looke
Vpon the price you gaue for this sad thraldome,
You'll feele your heart stabd through with many a woe,
Of which one dyes not while a thousand grow.
All will be then too late: Now is the time,
Now rings the warning bell vnto your breast:
Where if you can but entertaine a thought,
That tells you how you are beset with danger,
You are secue; Exclude it, you are lost
To endlesse sorowes, bought with dearest cost.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.L: Pray Sir deale freely with me. What respect
Moues you to make this strong disswasion?
Is it your care of me? or loue of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.L: A subtill question! This woman is not brainelesse.
Loue of him Lady? If this can be loue,
To seeke to crosse him, in so great a hope,
As your inioying; being all the meanes,
Or possibility he has to liue on;
If it be loue to him, to let you know
How lewd and dissolute of life he is,
By which his fortunes being sunke, he is growne
The scorne of his acquaintance, his friends trouble,
Bing the common borrower of the Towne.
A Gallant lights not a Iobacco Pipe,
But with his borowing letters (shee's not mou'd)
And if you put him off a fortnight longer,
Heel be layd vp for moneys he tooke vp
To buy his Knighthood; besides his deepe ingagements
To Goldsmith, Silkman, Taylor, Millener,
Sempster, Shoomaker, Spurrier, Vintner, Tapster,
(All stirres her not, shee stands as if prepar'd
To heare as much of truth and beare with it.)
Men of all Trades, and Occupations,
From his Mercer downward to his Waterman,
Haue venter'd the last sixpence on his Credit;
And all but wayt to pay themselues from you.
And I may well imagine how't would grieue
A woman of your wealth, to disburse all,
To saue a Knight out of his Ward i'th' Counter;
And lack with all his company at home;
While he frequents youthfull society
To make more charge for Nurseries abroad:
For I haue heard him say you are old; and that
It is your wealth he marries, d not you.
If this be loue to him, that I discouer
(The meanes to saue you to be his vndoing,)
Let no man take a friends help in hi wooing.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.L: And how this should proceed from care of me
Falls not into my vnderstanding Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri
SP.L: Considr Lady—

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.L: Sir I haue consider'd
Before, and in your speech, and since; and cannot
By all that can be said remoue a thought.
I lou'd him not for words: Nor will I vse
Words against yours: 'twere poore expression
Of loue to boast it. Tis enough I know it.
Boasters of loue, how can we Louers call,
When most of such loue one no more then all.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Sure, I was much mistaken in this woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.L: Nor would I haue you to expect a rayling,
To say you basely wrong the Gentleman:
A way so common, common women vse it.
But this Sir I will say, I were too blame
If I should thinke your loue to him were lesse
Then the great care of me, you seeme to vrge,
As you pretend it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.L: Shee will discouer me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.L: You are his Kinseman nearly; and reputed,
By his owne mouth, his best of chosen friends;
My selse an vtter stranger, one from whom
You neuer had, or can expect least good.
And why you should, for a respect so contrary,
Call my poore wit in question to beleeue you,
Is most vnconscionable.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.L: Me thinke I stand
Like a false witnes 'gainst anothers life,
Ready to take his punishment.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.L: Nor will I foudly thinke you meant to seeke,
Crossing his Match, to make it for your selfe:
Both for my knowen unworthinesse; and your
Deprauing him being no possible way
To make me thinke the better of your worth.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.L: Can this be shee? how strangely am I taken!

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.L: But I forgiue, and charitably thinke
All this brought no ill purpose; pretty Pageantry
Which may hereafter, 'mong our mariage mirth,
Fill vp a Scene: for now Ile take no notice.
Indeed I will not: you may, if you please,
And tell your Cuz how haynously I take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.L: If thou hast mercy, Loue, keep't from my heart.
Wil't please you heare me?

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.L: Sir I haue, enough.
And craue but leaue to speake this little to you,
Which shall by heauen be vncontrol'd as Fate.
If I shall find him bad, I'le blame my fortune:
Neuer repent or thanke you for your counsell.
If I shall finde him good; and all this false,
VVhich you so violently haue vrg'd against him;
Ile loue him nere the more, nor you the worse:
For I am not so poore, nor weakly spiritted,
That should all friends to whom my faith is bound,
Say on their knowledge, that all this were true,
And that one houres protraction of our Mariage
Should mak't appeare, that I would giue allowance
To all their bugbeare reasons, to deferre
That houre the vniting of our hands: because
Our hearts are link'd by the Diuinest lawes.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.L: What haue I done? The curse of ouer-weening brains,
Shame, and disgrace are guerdon of my paines.
O, I shall fall beneath the scorne of fooles:
A punishment as iust, as great for such,
That doe in things, concerne them not, too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.L: What ayles the Gent?

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.L: O what a setled rock of Constancie
She planteth her affection? not to moue,
Though all the breath of slnderous reproach,
Driuing tempestuous clowds and stormes of horror,
Should beat, at once, against it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.L: Sir How dee?

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: Ma-dame.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.L: Not you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri
SP.L: I would I had not seene, at least not heard her
In all so contrary to all opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.L: You are not well Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.L: They said she was old, vnhandsome, and vncuill,
Forward, and full of womanish distemper.
Shee's none of these: but opposite in all.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.L: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.L: My witty purpose was to saue my friend
From such a hazard; and to loath her so,
That I might make her loathsome to his fansie:
But I my selfe am falne into that hazard;
To wrong my friend; to burne in lawlesse loe;
Which oh that prayers or penance may remoue.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.L: You are not going Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.L: I beg your pardon; dare not look vpon you.—

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.L: Gone in a dreame▪ Well, I perceiue this iugling.
This straine was onely to explore the strength
Of my affection to my lucklesse Knight.
For which, if both their Cunnings I not fit,
Let me be call'd the barren wife of wit.

DIV3.TRAILER: The end of the first Act.

DIV3.HEAD: Act. II. Sce. I.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: The strangenes of this Gentlemans action will not out of my mind yet. Sir Phillip could not but haue a hand in it. Do's he repent his bargaine already; and desire to bee quit with losse of his earnest? Tis but his faith and troth.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Sister, where are you? My Governour and I are come to waite vpon you in sir Phillip Lucklesse coach. It waits at doore for you; and what to doe thinke you?

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: I can not tell. Perhaps to inuite me forth into the ayre of ideparke or Maribone; or else—

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Or else me no or elses, sister, you cannot guesse it. And I was a foole to aske you the question, now I think on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: That was well remembred brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Sister, you are to be a Lady, within this halfe houre. Your knight is ready, so is the Parson too. My Gouernour here knowes.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: Yes Lady; and that hee intreats you, to beare with the sodainsse of the occasion, which hee protests, deepely vrges him to be married presently; desiring you not to trou∣ble your selfe in examination of his reasons: for vpon his honesty and honour, the end of it is for good to you both. Come sweet Madame (now I am bold to giue you your dew title) your knight is ready prest on his aduontures (dee heare) and tis onely you, that hee seekes to incounter.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: There's a iest now: but shee vnderstands it not. He makes her an Infidell, a wild beast or a Monster, by that word Incounter; what doe Knights adventurers incounter else? looke all the Mirror over. Hee'll incounter her. O the wit of a Gouernour!

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: Tis as I say Madame, (dee heare) the good fit's come on him.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Ever at the tayle of his dee heare, I am sure to smell a iest: the fits come on him:

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P:
This sodaine importunity confirmes my former doubt: He thinkes his Scare-crow will make me keepe off
now; but hee is cossend. Well sir. He shall find me obedi∣ent to his hand. I am in all prepar'd to meet his purposes; Though, Brother I had thought to had conference this Mor∣ning with sir Paul Squelch touching a match for you.

SP.SPEAKER: VVid.
SP.P: For me sister: ha' you found out a wie for me? ha' you? pray speake, ha' you?

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: And a good match too brother; Sir Pauls Neece: on whom, hee, being childles, meanes to bestow a large Dowry.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
Fit.
SP.P: Hee is a right good man. Within there. En. Howd. Bid Flaps your fellow bring my Fan and Masque.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: Is hee bounteous and liberall ha? Do's he make large Suppers and lend money. Dee heare? Is he good at that?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Nay, there you mistake Gouernour. A good man i'th Citty is not call'd afer his good deeds, but the knowne weight of his purse. One, whose name any Vsurer can read without spectacles; One that can take vp more with two fingers and a thombe vpon the Exchange, then the great man at Court, can lift with both his hands; One that is good onely in riches, and weares nothing rich about him but the Gout, or a thombe Ring with his Grandsites sheep∣marke, or Grannams butter-print on't, to seale bags, acquit∣tancs and Counternanes.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mayd, Howdee, with Maske and Fan.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: A Butter-print?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: I twere a cunning Herald could find better Armes for some of 'hem: though I haue heard r Paul Squelch protest he was a gentleman, and might quarter a coat by his Wiues side. Yet I know hee was but a Grasier when he left the Countrey; And my Lord his father whistled to a teame of horses (they were his owne indeed.) But now hee is right worshipfull, and I would I had his Neece vnsight and vnseene I faith for her monies sake. You neuer heard mee aske if shee were faire or hansome, dee marke that sister? My fathers rule right. And if I be not a true Widgine. (God forgi' me) I thinke he was none.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: But shee is very faire brother, and very hansom and the prettiest innocent countrey thing withall. Doe I want nothing here?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: I now you bring me to bed sister.

SP.SPEAKER: May.
SP.P: Your Masque sits well forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: But where's my Wimple forsooth?

SP.SPEAKER: May.
SP.P: Vpon the Cupboards head, pray Humfrey fetch it.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Hee liues not that loues a Countrey thing like me▪ Alas none loues a Countrey thing lke mee. And though I am a Cockney, and was neuer further then Hammersmith; I haue read the Countrey mans common wealth; and can dis∣course of Soccage and Tenure, Free-hold, Copy-hold; Lease, Demeanes, Fee-simple and Fee-taile, Plowing, Hedging, Diking, Grubbing, occupying any Countrey thing whatso∣euer; and take as much pleasure in't, as the best Clowne borne of 'hm all.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.L: And shee is very young, aboue fifteene, brother.
How this fellow stayes! Goe you.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: And that's a safe age for a Maid in the countrey: dee heare?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Pardon me Gouernour. I doe heare and not heare thee at this time.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: And sings, and speakes so pretty northenly they say.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: Is shee Northern (dee heare) will shee not shrinke i' the wetting?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Gouernour, I know thou spokst a iest now, by thy dee heare: but prithee forgiue me; I cannot applaud nor marke thee at this time.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: What maks you stay so? I feare you haue beene among my sweet meats.

SP.SPEAKER: How.
SP.P: Shee said it was vpon the Cupboard; and it was vnder the Cupboard.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Is this my Wimple? Doe you bring Carpenters tooles to drsse me withall.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.P: Here is your Wimple forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P:
I shll teach you to know a difference betweene
gentlewomens geere and Carpenters tooles. I shall

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Nay, shee is so vext now I Deare sister to the Coun∣trey Lasse againe. You said, she spoke and sung Northernly. I haue a great many Southerne songs already. But Northern ayres nips it dead. Yorke Yorke for my money.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Yes brother shee is Northern, and speakes so: for shee has euer liu'd in the Countrey, till this last weeke, her Vncle sent for er vp to make her his child, cut of the Bish∣oprick of Durham.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Bishop, nor Bishoprick shall hold her from mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: And brother—

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Sster no moe, though I haue never seene her. No Bishoprick i'th' land from me shall winne her. If you will goe, and clap hands with your knight, come; I would see you matchd first: because that will add some honour to the Widgine, when my selfe shall bee brother to a Lady. I shall write first of that name. And then am I no sooner married, Gouernour, but wee will set our trauels a foot: to know Countries, and Nations, Sects and Factions, Men and Manners; Language and Behauiour.
SP.L: And so in height of complement grow compleat
More goes to making of a Man, the meat.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: Pray tell me; and tell me truely. What is the most has past betweene you? I it bee the maine losse of your Mayden-head, it shall neare go further: theefore let mee know it.

SP.SPEAKER: Con
SP.P: As I liue Mistris Trainewell, all that ere he had o'me was but a kisse. But I mun tell yee, I wish'd it a thoosnnd, thoosand till him.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: How often haue you seene him?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Feath but that bare eance nother, and your seln were by too. Trow yee that Ide not tell yee and twere maer. By my conscience Mrs. Trainewell I lee not.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P:
That once that I saw him with you, your Vcle
was there, too, in the Orchard, but last weeke.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Vary true, Mine Vncle was than by too. And hee brought sir Phillip to see his Orchard. And what did hee than doe, trow you, but tuke me thus by th' haund, and thus hee kust mee; hee sed I were a deaft Lasse: but ther he feind. But for my life I could not but thinke, he war the likest man that I had seene with mine eyne; and could not devaise the thing I had, might be vnbeggen by him. Then by and by as we walkd, he askd mine Vncle, gin hee would giue him me to make a Lady till him. And by my trouth Mistris Trainwell, I lee not, I blush'd and luk'd vpon him as I would feine a hed it so: Mine Vncle said yes, and sir Phillip shuke my haund, and gude feath my heart ioyd at it. God gin the Priest had beene by. But I thought all sure enough; and would not ha' sold my part for the Spanish Ladies Ioincture. But streight anon mine Vncle and he fell on other talke, of Lords and La∣dies, and many foud like things, I minded not: For I is weell sure, this keept me waking ere sine. And God pardon mee what I misthought euery houre i'th' night.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: How haue you made me wrong this Gentleman, to challenge him as if hee had beene your due vpon this idle complement? when I vndertooke the Message, I presum'd (for so your words did intimae to me) you had beene sure, as fast as faith could bind you, man and wife. Where was my discretion? Now I perceiue this was but common Courtship; and no assurance of a Mariage promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: I wot not what he meant. But I is weell sure, Ile nere bee sure to ony Man but hee. And if hee loue mee not as weell, God pardon him. For I meant him none ill.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: I know not how to counsell or comfort you, vntill I heare him speake. My man tells me, hee appointed him to meet, and bring him to you about this houre. Poore heart I pitty thee. Before thou come to halfe my yeares thou wilt forget to loue halfe so truely.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: Mistris.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: O, are you come? where's the Knight?

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: He stayes below, and wild me to come vp first, to to make his passage cleare and secure.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: That was discretion.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: Rather feare I thinke: for he ask'd me if the house were not much haunted with Roarers or Swaggerers, poni∣ards and pistols: whether there were not an Assurer for it as vpon the Exchange, as i his life were vpon hazard? whe∣ther a Man might come on without losse of credit, and off without need of a Surgeon? Much odd talke hee deliuers; that in my conceit bewrayes, at once, both a asciuious and cowardly disposition; and vpon my vnderstanding, canot bee so generous, or nobly spirited, as hee is receiued. Doe what you will.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: I suspect something.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Will hee not come Mrs. Trainewell?

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: Yes sweetheart. But goe you to your Chamber and let me haue a word before you see him. Goe call him in. Doe so swetheart. Ile not be long.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Ile doe ought you bid me God gin I saw him eance.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: A place of faire promising! How haue I liu'd that never discouer'd this place before? This place royall! But sought my recreation, in by-lanes, and sluttish corners, vnsa∣uory Allies and Ditch sides? when here the whole house is perfum'd: An Earle might thinke it his owne lodging; Ladies might come to see the pictures, and not blush, to goe in or out vnmask'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: Sir, will you speake to my Mistris? The man is transported sure!

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: I vnderstand thy office, leads thee no further; thy paines are abroad and below stayres. Here honest Fetch. Looke thee, heres the poore price of a new paire of shooes; take it. Descend, and execute thy duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: Blesse me! this is another man. More abuse yet?

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P:
Now gentlevvoman to you. What fees belong to your Key? Come, vvher's the bed? vvhere's the party?
Here's the man: her's the money. Chunke chunke you old Gamster, dost heare? Here's halfe a peece to buy tee com∣plection, sack or Aqua-vitae. What thou lik'st.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: What are you sir I pray?

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: Faith one thats a little ill giuen at this time. Where's the ece? here are the peeces tell thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: What peece sir? If you can imagine what you are, where you are, what you would haue, or where you would be, I pray tell mee sir. le doe the best I can to satisfie you. O' my discretion will I sir.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: Giue me but a little space to wonder at thy strange demands and I wil tell thee, good discretion. If I should pur∣chase a broken Cockcombe, or bruz'd ribs now, for mista∣king another mans habit, the smart were onely mine. The villaine swore to me, his Master was sent for; and that his Master swore this ws a Bawd to his choyce Whore, newly intertayn'd; and that shee knew not him, and might well mistake me for him. On which presumption I hae waded thus farre: and if I sticke in the Mud, or be driuen backe by a tempest, I am armd. Tis not the first time I haue beene Wether-beaten, or Dry-beaten, dee heare?

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: You doe not know me? or, at least, not remember mee?

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: If I erte therein sir, I hope your pardon. For as you shall reueale your selfe, I shall either repent me of my obliuion, or accuse you of vnaduisednesse.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: Shee speakes like the wife of an Orator, that could dictate her husbands speeches! Were not you this Mor∣ning at sir Phillip Lucklesse lodging? spoke not you with him? sent you not for him afterwards to repaire hither to the party? And know you not the man?

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P:
O infinite abuse! Sir I cry you mercy. I hope you will pardon my weake sightednes. The worlds ad and we loue to deale securely. Could not your worship make your selfe knowen sooner? Please you to entertaine you selfe here a while, I will instantly prouide for your better wel∣come. O horrible indignity! But if Porters and cudgels
may be had for money, and I fit you not, let me loose my dis∣cretion. I am furnisht with blankets already.—

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: I will instantly prouide for your better welcome! Will you so? Twill passe: and by this light I thinke for my Masters iest: I will recouer my chardges, and gaine over and aboue for three returnes more with the bare repetition of it out of one mas puse, the Widgine. My iests are his nu∣triment; and my wit is his own, he payes so duely for it. If the Wench be but pleasing, now, o my expectation, my fe∣licity is crown'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: O child, wee are vndone.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Mary, God sheild Mrs. Trainewell. Is hee geane? Must I not see him?

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: A lasse it is not he: but some Villaine snt by him to vexe and spite you. One that perswades himselfe, we are of those common creatures▪ that sell their honesties.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Heauen blisse vs, and giue vs leaue to dee first. Can he be so vnkaind, to scorne me so, Woe i me.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: He is so dishonorable. But I wi fit his Vnderta∣ker, what ere he bee. Looke you, is that he thinke you?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: O Weell a neare Mistris Trainewell! Sir Phillip is the likest man that ere you saw dayes o' your life. This Lo∣zell dow not. Nor would he send him. So trim a Man can∣not haue ike bad purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.P: Mistris, theres a Gentleman, one Master Tridewell, that sayes he is sir Phillips Kinseman, will by all meanes speak with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: Sweet heart, can you dissemble your sorrow with a Song, to passe a little time? Ile downe and sift out the sub∣tlety of this deceit.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: There is no gouernment vnder the Sunne, like the politique gouernment of a Bawdy-house.

LG.HEAD: Song.
LG.L: You say my Loue is but a Man.
But I can find more ods.
Twixt him and others then I can,
find betweene him and Gods.
H has in's eye
such Maiestie.
His shape is so diuine.
That were I Owner of the world.
Hee onely should be mine.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: Sweet prologe to the insuing Intertude Ent. Bea. Dost heare me honest fellow? was this the Parties voyce?

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: Onely hers vpon my sincerity sir.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: Excellent! Shee has rais'd my desire aboue her noates. Why am I ths rauishd, and yet delayd?

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: Sir, for that my Mistris craues your Pardon. Tis not her neglect, that workes vpon your patience; But the necessity to rid a troublesome Lord or two out of the house, beore the Party can appeare to you. But please you to ob∣sucre your selfe in this darke Clset, while I conuey them hence, and then, instantly, the top Gallant of pleasure shall crowne your Maine-mast, shee sayes.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: O how her wit and care reviues me! From hence forth shee is my Bawd for euer. My discretion! But are they wholsome Lords Sirah?

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: Tis no matter for any thing they did here sir, I war∣rant you. Inquickly pray si.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: Must I be lockd in?

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: You cannot be safe else sir.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: The politique gouernment of this little common wealth!

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P:
Indeed Lady, I am so farre from being in any plot herein, that I protest it was merely by his outside, and that in the dobtfull light of the Euening, that I could guesse twas hee. An had he beene denyed, I had gone well satis∣fied, it had beene some other man. Which if it proue, and so his name be abus'd—Or if it be he indeed, though hitherto
my most respected Cosen, that offers such an outrage, as you deliuer it to be: I am so much a friend to honesty, that let me but see the man or beast, Ile doe the faire office of a Gentle∣man to right you. Indeed Lady I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: You professe nobly sir. First will it please you, see this Gentlewoman; so much the seruant of your Kinsman? What shee is I haue told you. Only I present her to your iudgement, whether her outward seeming may dsrue such scorne?

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Alasse faire Lady, would they iniure you?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Yea feath, and scorne me too sir. Ill betide them. But and you doe me helpe, and ma' sir Phillip loue me, God reward you.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: And has your youth and bauty plac'd your loue on him?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Gude eath sir, I may not say how well I loue him: But were I one of neere a mickle, heest eene haue all. And yet he loues me not.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Indeed tis pittifull. Weepe not sweet Lady. He shall loue yee.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Now Gods benison light o'yee for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Shew me the mischiefe, that hath abus'd vs all. Can you conceale him longer?

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: For our owne ight, to doe our selues misdeed. There∣fore take this in hand.—

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: You doe instruct me well. Pray let me see him.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: Oh for a large Window, one of the last edition, to leape out with halfe my life or limbs.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Lo yee lo yee, the worst like man to Sir Phillip yee saw in all your dayes.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Mischeiuous Diuell! What magicall madnesse con∣iur'd you ito this shape?
Indeed Ile coniure you out on't.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: Oh hold: for heauens sake hold. Ile confesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Nay, indeed Ile beat you a little first, you'll confesse the better. Twill come the easier from you. Tis a good preparatie.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: Oh! oh, ile cofsse any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: No sir, nt any thing. But the truth the truth sir.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: The truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth hlpe me—

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: You would be swearig now would you? there's for tht.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: No indeed, indeed, and indeed la I will not.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: God sir no more. What may this poore thing bee, that br' it o bu nw?

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Ile tll you Lady. The most notorious, base, beatn Rascall out the Towne. Twere lst breath to say more by him. He is as you see▪ Onely is name is Anvile: and they that know him not, call im Capaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: Anvile? Pray sit let me try in▪ blade on him too.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: I pray thee doe, to laue me a lbour: for hee is not hlf batn yet.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: Oh, oh. Ladies speake for me. ha' you no mercy?

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: Hold. No more.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Well sir, thanke the Ladies. Now sir, put this La∣dies fauour here in your pcket; and keepe it there till I call fr it. And marke what I say, if ever I find thee without this Instrument or the like, when I shall call for it, to beat the (marke me) indeed le eat thee . And now to your xamination. How got your rotten Mutton ship into this Lyos case? was it by the Owners knowledge? was the Master of these Cloathes priuy to your vndertaking? Answer sirah, bonafide, I or no.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: No vpon my life; only his Man abus'd mee for my Moey.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: What presumption made you thinke so vilely of thee Getlewomen?

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: Sir Phillips owne words to his Man, vpon a letter this Lady deliuer'd to him this Morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P:
The Error's found. Her name you say is Constance,
which likewise is the name of a prostituted Strumpet, with whom, tis thought, the wantonnesse of his youth hath held former familiarity; and now it seemes makes doubt, imagi∣ning that letter to be hers, that she pretends a claime to him.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: Right sir: which hee tooke so contemptuously, that instantly he resolued to mary the Widow, Mistris Fit∣chow; and was this Morning married priuately in a Cham∣ber, within an houre after you saw him.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: And I vndone than.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: And I if it bee so.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: It is vndoubtedly true. I saw them married, and di∣ned with them, at his lodging, where they will sup too: But after Spper they goe to her house in the Towne to bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: This fole mistaking we shall all repent; if we pre∣unt not what may issue from it.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: Alas sir all will be too late.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Will you but trust my seruice for your honour?

SP.SPEAKER: Ta.
SP.P: Wee will waite on you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.L: Then Sir for this time you shall be repriu'd,
rom further penance: Rise and be our Guide.
But kepe your feare still: for if all out art
Miscarry, thou art sure to share the smart.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: Brother Humrey, take my hand and word for thy instructions. I will acquaint thee with an old Ladies Vsher, in the Strand, that shall giue thee thy Gait, they Postures, thy Language, thy Habit, and thy whole chardge in so plain a Method, that thou shalt instantly start vp as pretty a Genle∣man Vsher, none disprays'd as any betweene Temple-bar and Charing-crosse; mary further I cannot promise you Bt prithee tell mee. Is our Lady of so hot a temper and stately cariage as shee is reputed?

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.P:
O I brother. Shee must command all, or all shall smoke for't. Shee did so in my old Masters dayes I a .
And hee glad of peace at that rate too.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: But how is she to her seruants? Bountifull and free?

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.P: Ys both of her voice, and hans.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: Shee will not strike will shee?

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.P: And she could bite as well, the rankest Iade that ere was curried could not come neate her.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: Heauen be good to vs! she nere strooke thee, did she?

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.P: Tis no matter for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: Nay brother, you know we haue vow'd to be all one: the Mariage hath vnited vs. Prithee tell mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.P: Shee broke mee a tooth once with a deaths Head∣ring on her finger? it had like to ha' cost mee my life! 't has bene a true Memento to mee euer since: bobs o' the lips, tweakes by the nose, cuffs o'the eare, and trenchers at my head in abundance.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: Will shee throw too?

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.P: Any thing shee can lift. and makes vs pay for all shee brekes, though shee breake our heads or races withall. Fan-handles, Lookng-glasses or any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: Wee shall haue a foule h use on't I feare But since it is too ate, fight Dog, fight Bare. Ile turne my Master loose to her. Here they come. By this light me thinkes they looke as if they were fallen out already.

DIV3.HEAD: Act. II. Sce. VI.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lucklesse, Fitchow, Wayting-woman, Widgine, and Bulfinch. At the other dore Squelch, Nonsense, and Beauis.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Though I were absent at the Ceremony, I now bring my wishes of much ioy.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: And not too late I hope sir Paul. Wee may yet crry them to bed with vs▪

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: You had beene chiefly sir inuited, had we not stolne a day fr Time, to haue done a athers part at Church, to which yor absence, I intreated our worthy friend Mr: App hesion Bulfich ere.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Mstr Bulfinch, I reioyce t meet you here directly. Looke you sir. Doe you know this young Gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Bul.
SP.P: Yes sure, methinkes I should know him. But I am sure I neuer saw him before. ha—

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Haue you forgot sir Hercules?

SP.SPEAKER: Bul.
SP.P: I apprehend him to be Master Salom Nonsense, Son and Heire to my right worthy friend, sir Hercules Nonsense of Cornewall. If you be not hee sir. I am sure it is you. I my bee deceiu'd, but I am certaine tis hee.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Hee is doubtfull, but yet hee is sure hee knowes him. What a Bulfinch is this I sure tis his language they call bull-speaking.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: You say very well sir. And neuer credit me as you knew my Father, I would be very ready, as you know how duety binds: for because it is a vsuall thing in these dayes, desiring the loue and friendship, I protest and vow sir. I shuld—

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Most perfect Nonsense! this is a finer youth then tother. My wiues acquaitance are most answerable to her Kinred.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Tis so dirctly Master Bulfinch, and I haue brought him to Towne—I vnderstnd my Nce is in your house, my Lady Bride. Is shee employd in your Chamber?

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Shee is not here sir. Is shee Howdee?

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.P: Certes no Ma-dame.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: How! not here? Sirh what did you tell me?

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: What shall I say or doe? hang'd directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: How was shee accompanied?

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: By my Mistis sir, and Gentlemen of her ac∣quaintance, whose names I know not.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Kmuery, Villany and heuery! sll it ranke. Shee's stolne, shees gone directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Tis indirectly sir if shee bee stolne. There your word failes you.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: If shee bee in the land I will recouer her, I hope I shall find much right in Law, as a Broaker or a Ioyner.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Good sir Paul, I haue not seene you thus dm∣perd. What aflicts you?

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Oh Mistris Fitchow, my Neece, my Neece.

SP.SPEAKER: Widg.
SP.P: Hee's mad I thinke. Sir you forget my sister is a lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Shee's is lost, shee's stolne, and all my ioy is gone. My Neece my Constance.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Constance!

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Who your young Neece that came lay out of the Countrey?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: My Countrey thing sister, that you promis'd me?

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Promis'd you? I am abus'd. I doe suspect you ac∣cessaries. Sir I haue purpos'd and promis'd her to this Gentleman. And here I charge you to restore her me.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Are you the Man si that must haue her?

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: Neuer credit mee sir, if I haue her, or haue her not to my knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Sir Phillip, you are courteous and noble: as you will continue so in opinion of honest men, let me haue right.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Sir Paul, vpon my faith I am ignorant of any such wrong. And, for her part, should shee fare amisse, I should suffer in her iniury equally with your selfe: for I profes to you, I did loue the Lasse so well; and at the first sight, that had I not beene otherwise allotted, and indeed contracted to her, from whom now there is no starting, shee should haue beene my Bride, if all my loue and fortune might haue wonne her.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Had you spard this Protestation, Sir, you might haue dissembl'd your loue to me the better.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Dissemble?

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Tis said sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: By this hand my Ladie's iealous already.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.P: Blesse vs! what lookes are these!

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Sir I must take my leaue, this is no time to trouble you.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Nay good sir stay, and share in our ill Banquet. Harke, some friend I hope. Looke firah.—

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Some of your old companions haue broght you a sit of Mirth. But if they enter to make a Tauerne of my house, ile add a voice to their consort shall drowne all their fidling. What are they?

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: Some that come in gentile fashion to presee a Maske.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Locke vp the dores, and keepe them out.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Breake them open and let them in—

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Shall I not bee Master of my owne house?

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Am not I the Master of i and you—

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Nay sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Passion of my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Bu. Madame, Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: you must allow of reasonable things.

SP.SPEAKER: Bu.
SP.P: Be contented, sir Phillip in a noble Gentleman, and a Courtier, and as I apprehend.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: I dare warrant you sister these are of his friends, that come with their Loues to congratulate his fortune. Speake Master Nonsense. A speech of your would do't.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: Neuer credit me, but I for sooth am of that opinion, that it is as it were. I protest and vow—I should be as sor∣ry as any Man.—

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: It this were to bee put into latine now. Which were the principall Verbe.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: M. Nonsense, you haue preuaid. You see Iam content. But what I purpose, Fate shall not preuent.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Did I not tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: More lights, and let them enter. Gentlemen take your places. Sir Paul to night forget your sorrow. So will I mine, though I renue tomorrow. Come sit sit. Mstris please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: You wrong your honour sir, your most humble Hand-maid.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Brother I told you alwayes shee had hasty humors, and as vnreasonable as heart can wish: but soone over. Now shee's as mild as any Doue againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Then wee are friends; and shee's my Doue againe.
SP.STAGE: The Masquers Enter. All in willow Garlands. Foure Men. Foure Women. The two first payres are Tridewell and Con∣stance. Anvle and Traine well. Before the Danee, Constance sings this Song.

LG.HEAD: Song.
LG.L: Nor Loue, or Fate dare accuse,
For that my Loue did mere use;
But oh mine owne unworthinesse,
That durst presume so mickle blisse.
It was too much for me to lou
A Man, so like the Gods aboue;
An Angels shape, a Saint-like voie,
Are to Diuine for Humane choice.
Oh had I wishly gi'n my heart,
For to haue lou'd him but in part;
Sought onely to enioy his face;
Or any one peculiar Grace
Of Foot, of Hand, of Lip, or Ey,
I might haue liu'd where now I dye.
But I presuming all to choose
Am now cdomned all to loose.

DIV3.STAGE: At the end of the Daunce, Tridewell and Constance Whisper with Anvile, each of them giuing him a folded paper.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Tis well perform'd. Now we would gladly know. To whom we owe our thankes.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: That Ile deliuer to you. Meane while the rest de∣sire they may withdraw a while.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Light and all faire respect be giuen vnto them.—

DIV3.STAGE: Exet all the Masquers but Anvile.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: The Womans voyce had much in't like my Neece.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: our Nece sir Paul, ods me I must goe see her.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Nay brother giue them all their free pleasures. By your leaue you shall stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: shll? I will then.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: Now to your I disclose my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P:
Whoo Gouerour: Looke you sister. Looke you hillip. Did nor I alwayes tell you he was the wit the world? This was his owne inven∣tion e bee hang'd else. Sweet Gouernour the conceit of
the Willow, and why tho wearest it?

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: My selfe, onely to make the number in the Dance sutable. And so did all the rest to fulfill the fashion, only two excepted, that were the Leaders and subiect of the Dance. The one, your Cosen Tridewell, who holds himselfe a lost Louer, in that you Madame to whom his affection is wholly deuoted, haue made your selfe incapable of him, in being the lawfull right of another. This paper shewes him more at large.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Ist possible! Did hee for that so earnestly deswade me from her this Morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: I neuer saw him before this day, nor he me. These are tricks and studied fooleres to abuse me—

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Who was the other.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: Shee was your faire Neece sir Paul; the most dis∣consolate Beauty that ere I saw, giuing her selfe for euer lost vnto your loue sir Phillip, presuming you once promis'd her Mariage, of which shee made a claime this Morning by her Nurse, whom you revil'd by name of Bawd, calling faire Constance Whore; and to her more despight, hastned your Mariage sooner by day, then you before intended with this Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Constance! May that name in all other women bee accursed beyond themseLucs. Hell it selfe could not haue vapor'd such an error forth, as I am lost in. Constance! why was that name made her, that Saint-like Maids, when it brought to my mind a Diuels, nay worse, a Whores? to whom before was giuen.

SP.SPEAKER: Bull.
SP.P: Sir Phillip, and Madame, you apprehend these things as things done, when they are not things indeed, but as it were shew and deuise, as by the sequele you may at large apprehend.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: I am of your mind Master Bulfinch. And trust me I am glad my Neece was drawne into the witty conceit. For which with a new Gowne he thanke her.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Where is shee? I will endure no longer till I see her.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: The Masquers are all gone sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Gone Villine.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: They tooke their Coches instantly, and disperst themseLucs by wayes, I had no Commission to stay them.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Are you so sensible of her losse?—

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: My Neece might not withstanding her lost loue haue tane me home in her Coach.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: You shall haue mine sir Paul and my company so farre to see her; and whether their presentation were iest or earnest, I will not rest till I be satisfied; My Coach. le make no stay Seet-heart. Shee's gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Excellent! the Bride's stollen to bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: It should be so. I like the custome well.

SP.SPEAKER: Bull.
SP.P: or if you apprehend it rightly, it expresseth duety in the Woman to lye prepared for him; and loue in the Man, not to be slacke to mbrace that duety.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: A ptty Mrll A Womans duety to lye downe, and a Mans loue to get vp. One may learne something of these old fellowes euery day.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Therefore no Coach, no Company noble Knight. Pursue your home occasions, and God g'yee ioy.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Nay sir Paul. I protest.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Not a word more of it directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Take me with you good sir Paul to see your Neece. I find Master Nonsense here very indifferent, And I know will be the greatr oy to her to match but into the family of sir Phillip, of which I am a halfe Pillr now. Besides my sister made me halfe a promise of her in good saith, my ouerours my Witnesse, and I haue lou'd her euer since.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: But you neuer saw her face.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: No, but ile bee hang'd if I did not loue her Visor the best ere while, though I coud not tell whose twas, nor which was which.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Good Master Water Widgine, this is no time of night to diue into busines of this depth. It is Nestling time I take it. How thinke you Master Bulinch.

SP.SPEAKER: Bull.
SP.P: I apprehend it to be past 12 Clocke very neare.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Therefore what your sister hath promis'd you, let her performe if shee can; meane time this Gentleman is my choyse: come Master Nonsense, you haue had a long time of silence. Master Bulinch.

SP.SPEAKER: Bull.
SP.P: I apprehend you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Weell, e you to the Gate by your leaue Ex Omnes.

DIV3.TRAILER: The End of the second Act.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: What has shee written here? It is the same hand I read in the Morning.

I am not your cunterfeit, or vnchast Constance; But that on∣ly Constance, that truely loue you, and that will, if you liue not for me, die for you. Oh that could at any price or penance now redeeme one day! Neuer was hasty Match sooner repented.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Hee's me cholly mee thinkes. Slid my sister may lye long enough languishing for a Ladiship, if this fit hold him: for shee has it not really till he goe to bed and u her.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: Will you not goe to bed sir? wee waite for your pints.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: I will. But is it time? Brother, would you would doe me the fauour to inquire.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Yes, ile goe see for the Possets sake.—

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Captaine, deale fairely with me. By what means ioyned you with this society? or how grew so soone your trust or great acquaintance with them?

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P:
Without offence ile tell you. You know this Mor∣ning at your Lodging, there past some words betwixt mee, and your sullen Kinsman, Master—indeed la, Tridewell, and from him too much indeed for me, a profest Souldier to beare: But the place protected him. Till after vpon m∣ture consideration I made after him for satisfaction, thus
arm'd as you see. Purposing with this Ropes end to right me; and to maintaine that right with this sword, which I thanke Mars neuer yet faild me; as it hath well beene mani∣fested by the effusion of much vnworthy blood of my abu∣sers, in France, Spaine, Italy, Poland, Sweden, Hungary, all parts of Germany.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Good Captaine trauell not so farre in your relation: but come home againe to the businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: I haue vs'd it in some score or two of Sea fights too by the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: But to the matter Captaine; where met you my Cosen?

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: The first sight I recouer'd of him, was as he was en∣tring the house of the greasie Knight there, what call you him?

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Sir Paul Squelch?

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: Squelch, I a pox squelch him. I waited a quarter of an houre at his doore, for your Kinsman; and longer I would not, had he beene Kinsman to the Emperour, and my Enemy. Therefore in I went, told Master Tridewell in his eare, my comming was to call him forth, to dischardge the office of a Gentleman with his Sword, in answering those wrongs wherewith I held my reputation wounded. Was it not well, ha? Could a poore Gentleman say more? and that in ciuill fashion very priuately in respect of the company, not shewing any the least distemper, in looke or gesture. But the Women read presently in his countenance the whole matter; and briefly by their pretty perswasion I tooke ordinary satisfaction of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: What was that Captaine?

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: Why hee confes'd hee wrong'd me, was sorry for't, and so forth. What should we speake more on't. This you must not speake of neither. You must promise me that o' your honour, as you desire to heare what followes: I loue no ripping vp old sores.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Not a word I, Captaine vpon my word. What a Rascals this! to the point good Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P:
Then thus sir? I soone perceiu'd, their drist to ap∣pease,
& winne me to their friendship was for my assistance, and indeede to beare the out in this nights worke, the Maske. The whole plot of all which was meerely to so we dissention betweene you and your new married Lady, to worke if they can a seperation, before carnall copulation, in which if they can prevaile, and that the dislike continue be∣tweene you to that height, that a divorce be required equal∣ly by the consent of you both, your Marriage then is frustra∣ted, and you stand in stat quo prim dee heare. So your Cosen Tridewell may lawfully pursue his hopes in your Bride, whō he loues as eagerly as the melancholly virgine dotes on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: But may this hold good in Law Captaine?

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: There's a Ganon for it Sir. If both parties agree to a divorce after Marriage, so it be before Copulation.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: Though the former part of his discourse, was a most egregious lye, yet the last hath some sound of pleasure in it: which I may make vse of.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
