SP.P: This fellow speakes.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Anv. widg. Holdup. and Howdoe disguis'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Bul.
SP.P: As I am a Iustice of Peace I cannot apprekend, and yet me thinks I doe. What sort of people these Gentlemen may be. See: more I Is sir Paule turn'd swaggerer? Or is his house abus'd by servants? I vvill not leaue it, vntill they goe out be∣fore mee like a layle deliuery. They loke like men betwixt a Repriue and Pardon. Friend: Are these sir Paules elected friends?

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: His protected friends sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bul.
SP.P: Protected?

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P:
I sir. There is a fraternity of them. The brothers of
the Protect. There's not a man of 'hem, but has all Mayors, Sheriffes, Bayliffes, Sergeants at Mace, Marshalls men, Consta∣bles, and other his Maiesties Officers, in a Combcase in his poc∣ket. They are a Generation that never eate but in Parliament time, and now every table is full of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Bul.
SP.P: I should wonder what they did here else. See. A roa∣ring Doctor too, broke out o' the Kings Bench.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: By your leaue Gallants. I perceiue your Company is not yet full.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Are you of the invited sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Pat.
SP.P: It is not to be doubted sir. Yet a Voluntary. But there are some without that are more then invited, yet come against their wills.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: How meane you M. Doctor?

SP.SPEAKER: Pa
SP.P: Brought sir by a Constable and Officers, to be examin'd. Where's the iolly Iustice?

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: What are they can yee tell sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: A Gentlewoman, and a Spaniard.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: A Spaniard, Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: I, a Spaniard, Ha: if you will haue it so:

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: If we had but a Iustice among vs to Examine 'hem, it might passe the time well till sir Paule came.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: Sir, here is a Iustice, and for the same purpose too for ought we know, that shall not resuse to doe it, and in sir Paules Gowne and Cap too.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: This is a witty fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: Sir, you cannot doe a more acceptable office for your friend, then to execute his place in his absence. Your anthori∣ty makes you capable of it; and I doe the rather perswade it, be∣cause the Gentlemen whom you wisely suspect for loose per∣son, may see some example of Iustice; which may preuent some present euill in their stay here.

SP.SPEAKER: Bul.
SP.P: I apprehend you friend. Giue mee the Gowne and Chayre, and let the Delinquents approach. Vmh, vmh.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Tis a Spaniard indeede.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Vexhem, Squelch, like a Spaniard, Trayn. Cleark.

SP.SPEAKER: Vex.
SP.P:
An English Spaniard sir, And therefore the verier
knaue: as will bee prou'd I doubt not, to his shame, and my re∣nowne in the Common . By your Worships leaue.

SP.SPEAKER: Bul.
SP.P: What newes bing ou M. Constable?

SP.SPEAKER: Vex.
SP.P: Spanish newes sir. Wit please your Worship to exa∣mine the vertue of my Warrant, and then these Persons ae∣cordingly?

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Very good! I am brought before my selfe to bee exa∣min'd, and before a fine rable too! how the deuill brok this vn∣knowne Ntion into my house, or doe not I mistake it? My foolery has led me into a fine predicament. I will not yet dis∣close my selfe: but looke a little surther towards the event.

SP.SPEAKER: Bul.
SP.P: Are you a Spaiard sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Such a one as you see Signior.

SP.SPEAKER: Bul.
SP.P: See Signior. Hee speakes nothing but Spanish. The question will be how we shall vnderstand this Examinant.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Hey day!

SP.SPEAKER: Bul.
SP.P: I do see Signior I thanke the light, that you are a good∣ly man of outward parts, and ezcept it were the black Knight himselfe, or him with the Fistula, the proprest man I haue seene of your Nation. They are a People of very spare dyet, I haue eard, and therefore seldome fat. Sue you you haue had most of your breding in this Cuntrey, the dyet whereof you like better then your own, which makes you linger here, after all you Country men, vpon ome vnouch plot. And I shall won∣der therefore how you can speake no English. Can you speake no English at all sir? Answere me I pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Not an English word not I s. Alasse I haue not been siue ayes in the Kngioe.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: This is excllent!

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: I, peace Y u'll marre all if you laugh.

SP.SPEAKER: Bul.
SP.P: , what shall wee doe then? Gentlemen, haue any of you any Spanish, to helpe mee to vnderstand this strange Saget?

SP.SPEAKER: Ti.
SP.P: Not a Riall sir not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Nor a Rialls worth amongst vs of any language but sher English.

SP.SPEAKER: Bul.
SP.P: What Siere of our Nation is next to Spaine? Perhaps he may vndrstnd that Shir, English.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Deuonshire or Cornall sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Nn.
SP.P: Neuer credit me, but I will spowt some Cornish at him. Peden bras vidne whee his cregas.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Am I transform' vtterly? Is my Language alter'd with my apparell, or are you all mad? what vnspeakeable misery is this.

SP.SPEAKER: Bull.
SP.P: I see we shall neuer vnderstand, nor doe good on him, till hee be instructed in the English tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Vex.
SP.P: And please your worship, the best Vniuersity for this pur∣pose will be Bridewell. I am acquainted with the best Tutors there, Master Cleanewhip, Master Drilash, and diuers others.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: You olicious Rascall, are you mad?

SP.SPEAKER: Vex.
SP.P: No such matter sir. But in my right mind, and Midlesex feare it not.

SP.SPEAKER: Bull.
SP.P: It must be so. His instruction will cost litle there, if hee be not too old to learne. Therefore set him by, and let mee fall vp∣on the Gentlewoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Vex.
SP.P: Oh, hee's rarely vext.

SP.SPEAKER: Bull.
SP.P: Now Gentlewoman, will it please you to be vnmasqu'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: Yes sir looke you, I dare shew my face.

SP.SPEAKER: Bull.
SP.P: Mistris Trainowell, as I apprehend.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: Mistris Trainewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Trainewell!

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: Euen shee Gentlemen, as I will more circumstantially re∣ueale vnto you presently, after a word or two with my fellow pri∣soner, for which I craue your fauour.

SP.SPEAKER: Bull.
SP.P: With all my heart, so you can speake Spanish and make him vnderstand you.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: You see I am not the Woman you tooke me for: but one ordain'd for your greater good. If you will giue me my present demand. I will turne all your disgrace into laughter; make you of worthier esteeme now at the instant, then euer you were, by the generall approbation of these, and all that know you beside. Your Neece to shall be restor'd to your owne liking, and all shall be as well as you can wish. Otherwise, if you haue a mind to bee euerlastingly sham'd, by being perpetually laught at, take your owne course, Ile take mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: I am astonish'd. What is your Demaund?

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: Whereas your purpose was to make a Whore. Make me your honest Wife; no more. Bee sodaine in your resolue, all will be naught else.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P:
I am in a mischieuous streight then. Redime to captum. Thy wit deserues my loue. Ile do't; here's my hand and faith, Ile
do't. Tho art mine, and I am thine directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: Then earke you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri
SP.P: Sir what will you say, if this Gentlewoman conuert the Spaniard, turne him true English subiect, and present him to you with the oaths of Alegiance, & Spremacie in his mouth presently?

SP.SPEAKER: Bull
SP.P: I wil say, she eerues or euer hereafter to hold her peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: Now bear vp sir. Looke confidently, and say, you put on your Disguise purpsely to intertaine disguis'd Guests. Come a∣uant with your Picca de goat, and beginne with the Iustice here.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Thou hast made me a Mn for euer, and I will make thee a Woman directly. Gallants saue you. See here the Metamor. phosis, that meanes to metamorphose you all. Alas I know you for all your Disguises, and thought to intertaine you in your knd.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: Sir Pul Squelch!

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Ist out of you, my Vsurper, and most Vpstartical Iustice, whose olice is your trade, and Clearke your Prentice, I will draw a man of litle, or no Moment: yet my frend, and Master Bulfinch, out of the Chaire of Iustice. his my prognosticate the pting of my selfe, or many others out of Commission with∣in these few yeares; though I am no Prophet. Doe I speake English now? Doe I know you now, or you me?

SP.SPEAKER: Bull.
SP.P: Question , we should know one another sir Paul: or else oe of vs two were both very ignorant.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: To proceed in my Metamorphosis. I will change you most confus'd Roarer, into an accomplisht Knight. And bid you welcome, noble sir Phillip Lucklesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: I like the change well, and thanke you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Next sir of you Roarer, or Iieter, or whatsoeuer you are, I will make a compleat Gentleman, most answerable to you name Master Tridewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Very well sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: But out of you Master Doctor, I will pick a certaine Knane. Were is my Neece slrah?

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: Which of your Neces sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Haue I so many sir? I meane my only one Constance, find her me, r I will translate you out of an Aesculapian Cocke into a Newge ird immediatly.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Sir if you will Metamorphose me out of a Batch lor, into a Bridegroome, Ile shew you your Neece.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: This my Neece?

SP.SPEAKER: Vex.
SP.P: O haue I found you Mistris? Sir this is the Gentlewoman I brought before your worship to day.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Hold they peace; art in thy right mind?

SP.SPEAKER: Vex.
SP.P: As I am in my right mind and Midlesex, it is she sir. I had not matter enough then to lay to her charge; for which I thanke your worship I kist Newgate. But now I haue sir; she has lest a Child vpon our Parish, I am sure got by an vnknowne fa∣ther; and has beene a loose Liuen, both at Duke Humfreyes, and most of the winkd it houses about the Towne these foure yeares: which I can sufficiently proue.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Hold thy peace Knaue. Ile put these plums i' thy mouth else

SP.SPEAKER: Hold.
SP.P: Sir, my Child shall trouble your Parish no longer, here is a Father, my troth plight Husband, sufficient to keepe it and me, wilt thou not Duck?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Duck? my name is Widgie, you mistake the man sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Hold.
SP.P: Sure I doe not. This Gentleman, and this Gentlewo∣man, and this trusty Seruant of ours are my witnesses, I am your Wife sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: O I am vnone, quite cast away. Sister helpe mee now with your Law wit, or I perish for euer.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: This is not to bee endured: cheating, and vile abuse, This contract can not bee lawfull. One person mistaken for another a lawfull impediment to be diuore'd for, though they were married.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: I might doe well if (as hee conesses himselfe) he had not made all too sure, as well within as withut.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Sir Phillip, while they wrangle out their cause, lt vs a∣gree: Find you but the meanes to make her lawfully your Wife, and here take her with my faithfull promise, of the equall halfe of any estate presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Sir Paul I thanke you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: I say this is no lawfull contract: And though we are le∣gally diuorc'd, yet neither he nor I may lawfully marry, while w both liue, hauing beene lawfully married. And till you can dis∣proue that, sir Ile forbid your Banes good sir Phillip, and lay your hopes a cooling, frendly Master Tridewell, for your loue in mana∣ging this businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Lady giue me leaue, if I haue strayn'd a point of friend∣ship, it was your loue gaue the strenght to my wit. Fit. loue?

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Your loue indeed Lady. Which (and which Cupid par∣don me for) now, that I see I may enioy, I am not so eagerly ta∣ken with, yet if you will—

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P:
Sir you cannot enioy me, not he her, lesse you can disproue
the lawfulnesse of our former Mariage.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri
SP.P: To cleare that point, doe you know the Minister?

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Tis not so long since, but I can remember his face.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Then to continue sir Pauls Metamorphosis? Ile draw him out of this Doctor. Is not this hee?

SP.SPEAKER: Fit
SP.P: It is. But is not hee a lawfull Minister; I would know that.

SP.SPEAKER: Pate.
SP.P: To cleare that doubt there lyes my Order of Priesthood.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: Who, Oliuer!—

SP.SPEAKER: Pate.
SP.P: Euen hee, the Parson Nochurch, and this my Patron, whom I must beseech together with the whole company, to preserue me out of the high Commission: for looke you, here is againe your Licence.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: Would you doe this Master Tridewell?

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: Faith I foresaw an vnto wardnesse in the Match: which if you repent the breach of, there's your Licence; and the way to Church lyes before you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: No sir. First get my brother free of his contract, and then a Licence with your owne name, and Ile waite on you to Church, as soone as you will.

SP.SPEAKER: Tri.
SP.P: O that's done already. What are ou agreed?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Most happily sir, sister alls well againe. I haue giuen her a hundred pound to relinquish her right in me. Which afore all these witnesses you doe; doe you not?

SP.SPEAKER: Hol.
SP.P: Yes most freely.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Well then, I will not for∣sweare to marry, But if euer I steale a Wife againe, let her be a witch, and may I ourn with her for company. Gouernour, thou art out of countenance, and thou too honest Humfrey, me thinkes. Come beare vp. I forgiue. Twas your errors, not malice.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.P: Sir for my part, ile take my corporall oath—

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: It sll not need good Humfrey.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: And for me sir—wid. Nay, I dare not but beeleeue the before thou speakest Couernour: therefore prithee lets not talke o't our selues, but quietly, and presently beginne our trauels, that we may heare no body else talke on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Gentlemen and Ldies, I ee you all at peaceo well, that I wish no further content to any, except Master Nonsense hre.

SP.SPEAKER: Nons.
SP.P: Neuer credit me but I haue had sport enugh'o conscience, and if I doe not make a Stage phyen't, when I come into Cornewall: I protest and vow then say there was Nonsense in this.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: I am glad you conclude so rendly with the rest. All the vnquietnesse will be in the Kitchin presently If your meat stay for you. Gallants. Knock Within I was time to speake. They knock at Dresser already. Will yee in?
SP.L: You re all Welcome: And I wish euery Guest
as merry, as our Northern asses Feast.
